channel.title: Transcripts: Prof G Pod (Scott Galloway)
channel.description: YouTube video transcripts from Prof G Pod (Scott Galloway)

item.title: Trump SPARKS Culture Wars MELTDOWN to Bury the Epstein Scandal
item.description:
Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov explore a weekend that showcased two very different Americas: Bad Bunny celebrated unity across the continent, while Donald Trump leaned into culture wars, attacking an Olympic skier for expressing mixed feelings about representing the U.S. and amplifying a racist video of the Obamas. At the same time, Congress is reviewing Epstein files, Ghislaine Maxwell is publicly hinting at clemency deals, and Trump’s allies are facing political scrutiny. They also break down Trump’s economic message ahead of the midterms — from AI-driven growth claims to foreign investment promises — and whether everyday Americans are actually seeing the benefits. Plus, they tackle the skyrocketing cost of NYC private schools, now topping $70,000 a year at elite institutions, and what it means for families navigating a struggling public system.
00:21 How Trump stirs culture wars to distract from Epstein 22:41 Trump’s economic pitch ahead of November elections 32:47 If private school is worth it
Follow Jessica Tarlov, @JessicaTarlov Follow Prof G, @TheProfGPod Follow Raging Moderates, @RagingModerates
Subscribe to our YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@RagingModerates
item.content:encoded:
[00:04]

Welcome to Raging Moderates. I'm Scott Callaway >> and I'm Jessica Tarlov. >> Today we're going to talk about how Trump stirs culture wars to distract from Epstein, Trump's economic pitch ahead of November elections, and if private school is worth it. If you haven't already, please make sure to subscribe to our YouTube page to get up-to-date coverage on everything happening. All right, let's get into it. Over the weekend, two very different versions of America on display. One on stage, Bad Bunny turned a major pop moment into a celebration of joy and unity, naming every country across the Americas and reminding audiences that America is bigger than any one flag or administration. At the same time,

President Trump was doing what he's done for years, picking cultural fights. He went after an Olympic skier for expressing mixed feelings about representing the US, amplified a racist video depicting the Obamas, and once again leaned into grievance and division. And the timing matters because as Trump fuels these outrage cycles, Congress is quietly reviewing unredacted Epstein files, we should put unredacted around in quotes, Gelain Maxwell is publicly floating clemency for silence and senior figures tied to Trump, including his commerce secretary, are facing bipartisan calls to resign over

their Epstein ties. Jess, before we get into Ebstein, what stood out to you about the wave of culture war fights Trump picked over the weekend? What really stood out to me is how ineffective I feel like he's become. Like he's really lost his fast ball. You know, they think they call it the weave that he does, right? Where he like finds a way to get a question that he doesn't like and then he goes some other path and you know, somehow his base plus the extra 10% that voted for him or whatever, like understands what he really meant and all is forgiven. And it

doesn't really feel like that's happening anymore. um or at least when it comes to these culture war things like Epste, which we'll get into, people actually do care about it even though he continually tells them not to um on the Bad Bunny performance. Uh you don't spend a lot of time on Twitter. I think you spent zero time on Twitter actually. Um but it was really interesting to see prominent conservatives coming out and defending Bad Bunny's halftime show. um including Alexis Wilkins who's Cash Patel's girlfriend, the one that he's flying all

over the country to see on our dime. But she said Republicans need to unite and get on better messaging because this branding is fantastic and allows all Dems to get behind it also super aesthetic. Uh Chris Rufo uh super right-wing defended it. Um Nick Fuentes uh who does go through many phases um but he said it's literally fake outrage self ghettoizing being overly political pretending to like the things we have become the far-left that's about the obsession with you know the kid rock show and he said that looked like me

familiar that's like all my cousins I think I recognized a few people there and on the horrible racist video of the Obamas depicting them as apes that came out Laura Ingram um who hosts the 7 o'clock show on Fox had Caroline Levit on and asked her about it, said, "Can you really throw a staffer under the bus?" And Levit tried this, "Oh, well,

[03:05]

this is a leftist media narrative." And she's staring at Laura Ingram, right? Saying that this is a leftist media narrative. So, it feels like the [ __ ] is being called a bit more. I I'm not predicting some downfall of the Trump administration, but it it does feel like he is not hitting his marks in the same way and he's not able to dangle like one trans swimmer in front of people to get them to come over to his side and the people are actually

observing what's going on on the ground and uh formulating a not so positive view of Trump and co as a result. What did you think about the uh outrage over all the the cultural war stuff that's going on? >> Well, I first off, I have absolutely no interest in Bad Bunny. I couldn't name a song that he sings. But at the same time, I look at the economics of it. It was a brilliant move by the NFL. The NFL is investing in the future. People under the age of 18 are the majority are non-white and this is the most popular artist in the world. So, of course, they should have him as their halftime show.

And I thought the halftime show was optimistic and well produced. I I watched it the next day. So, I think this was a big win for the NFL. Um, and a big win. And I just, you know, I'm no no one on the Republican side has asked me, but for them for them in their carnival barkers to come out and say he wasn't speaking English, and how's that going to help them with the Latino vote? And >> yeah, >> these cultural icons have such a huge followership and these artists that to

not kind of and then I think what was even worse and again I'm biased here but Kid Rock's thing looks so sad. >> Yeah. >> It just looked like okay this is you know this is sort of what like if meth had a concert. It just felt really desperate. It felt really you know not very well produced and kind of weird. Um, so I don't I I think he picked the wrong culture war. They picked the wrong culture war here. The other observations, the things I found

most fascinating about the Super Bowl had nothing to do with Bad Bunny. But by the way, I think the the threads account of Elmo had it perfectly that Elmo just hopes both teams have a really fun time. And he said, "Bad Bunny isn't a bad bunny, he's a good bunny." Both both those made me laugh. But the thing I noticed was that a quarter of the ads were AI. >> Yeah. >> So it was sort of the AI bull. And the last time tech dominated was in 2022. It was called the cryptob because a quarter of the ads were crypto things like FTX

and Binance. We know what happened there. And then the time before that where you breached 25% of the Super Bowl ads being from tech companies was in 2000 and we know what happened there. So if economic history repeats itself, we're about to see a major draw down in AI. And the other thing that the Super Bowl kind of conoted for me was I think there's been an enormous transfer in

[06:06]

power and value from the betting sites. Remember the big ad a few years ago with Salahek as as um Cleopatra, it was bet MGM and companies like Flutter have been on a roll. Flutter [ __ ] the bed and missed its earnings. I think everyone's moving from wagering to these speculation markets. And I think you saw that in the Super Bowl, but I I think they're on, and again, I'm biased here. I think they're on the wrong end of the I I think it would have been genius for them to say, "Love the Super Bowl was great. Bad Bunny was was great." I I

just think they I I think being associated with Kid Rock, you just look lame. >> Yeah. But they like >> there is an inability to ever be graceful about absolutely anything. I mean they couldn't even I'm talking about the administration, not the examples that I read out, but they couldn't even deal with reality that like a straight couple got married at the Super Bowl show, right? like there's nothing more pro pro- family and a lot of people are pointing that out like this is quote your quote unquote

conservative values and you know I've seen the translations of the lyrics like yeah Bad Bunny says some dirty things like Kid Rock saying one of his original hits which is completely profane I know it was supposed to be his redemptive arc for when he found Jesus or whatever but like it's just [ __ ] entertainment for what like I >> you like some shows you don't like other ones. I certainly thought it was less politically hostile or whatever you want to call it than Kendrick Lamar's was. I mean, his message was together we are

America, God bless America, led with the American flag. >> It seemed lovely. It reminded me of uh Ronald Reagan's great speech where he said, "You can be an Italian and move to Switzerland, but you'll never be Swiss. You can be Japanese and move to Mexico, but you'll never be Mexico. But all of these people can move to America and be Americans." I just I love that and it's true, right? And seeing all those flags, you know, our our strength is that essentially we're the operating system

for every other country that aspires to be democratic and prosperous. The US used to be the operating system legally, morally, economically for the entire West and people who aspire to be like the West. And when I saw those flags, I just thought of it as, you know, their their different cultures mostly operating or aspiring to our operating system. Let's move on. Trump's commerce secretary, Howard Lutnik, is under bipartisan pressure over alleged lies about his relationship with Epstein. I don't know if you've seen here in the UK, there's calls uh Ky thinks there's a

70% chance that Kier Starmer is going down. Not because he's in the Epstein Files, but because he recommended a cabinet poster for someone who's in the Epstein Files. I mean, that's that's the bar here versus our president, who, by the way, this is just some fun facts. Trump is mentioned

[09:06]

in the Epstein Files more than Jesus is mentioned in the Bible or the term meth is mentioned in all eight seasons of Breaking Bad. >> That's my fun fact for the day >> as the main character energy. What do you think's going to any thoughts on what's going to happen with Secretary Lutnik here? >> Well, we're recording this mid testimony. So, I don't know what else will come out, but I people are going to be looking into whether he perjured himself, whether he said in any sort of official forum that he didn't associate with Jeffrey Epstein past 2005. I think it was in his confirmation hearing. Um

but he went to the island to have lunch with his brought all his kids there um in 2012. And I really think that you know it needs to be a far bigger part of the discourse on this that so much of this is happening after Jeffrey Abstein is a convicted sex offender that he is a registered sex offender in 2009 and business continued as usual um in many respects. Um, so I, you know, I think Letic would be an easy person to push

out. He seems dug in about Christy Gnome. Um, but Letick doesn't really bring a lot of positivity, um, or glow to the administration. And remember early on we were talking about how he was giving the worst interviews of anybody and they actually had to take him off of TV um, because he was doing such a crap job. Um, so I could see that happening. It's all part of just this overwhelming narrative um that's taking shape and you know three million documents that's

going to take months and months to be able to sift through and then also to be able to connect dots between things because sometimes you you know you see an email and you don't know what it's a response to, right? Or where it fits into the whole story. Um but I was watching uh Roana has done a couple long form podcast interviews with Shawn Ryan. Have you ever watched the Shawn Ryan show? >> I haven't. He's really interesting. He's a former Navy Seal. Um was a Blackwater contractor uh with the CIA. He has a podcast. They have like 5.5 million

subscribers on YouTube. Um very conservative guy and he is part of this new cadre of traditional Trump supporters that are losing their minds over the Epstein files. and not looking at this at all through a partisan lens, but just saying how is it possible that people in positions of power are not interested in getting to the roots of all of this to understanding what went on here, especially when it has to do with the abuse of children in many cases. Uh Jamie Rascin came out of the

viewing room and said that the youngest victim that they saw was 9 years old, >> right? We're talking a 9year-old. And I was thinking back, remember Megan Kelly a few months ago made that crazy comment like, "Well, we're not talking about 5-year-olds. We're talking about 14year-olds." And she was, you know, said, "I'm not justifying it." But well, now you're talking about a 9-year-old. So a 9-year-old is more like a 5-year-old, right, than is like a

[12:07]

14-year-old. They haven't gone through puberty, right? You're talking about a kid. And Roana was talking about how he and Thomas Massie uh want like a truth and reconciliation committee to be enacted to get to the bottom of this Epstein web, which I think would be interesting. It doesn't get people any solutions right off the bat, but it feels like it's very necessary because the questions you're getting more questions than answers from all of this. Like who is Jeffrey Abstein? John Ryan thinks he was a Mossad agent. I mean,

the connectivity to other nations. Um, oh my god. And the difference also in his business pre and post conviction is fascinating too. How he shifted to older girls, a lot of Russians and Eastern Europeans and was working in that part of the world. The kind of business deals that he was doing with heads of major financial institutions, his relationship with the Rothschilds, for instance, these titans of tech. I mean, Roana said he's I represent a lot of these guys, right? He's the Silicon Valley

congressman and there splatter Elon Musk, Peter Teal all over it. So, you know, questions. Was he a foreign intelligence asset? Was he a US intelligence asset? He had access to the CIA for God's sakes. Like, he was in skiffs. So, who is this guy? And I've also shifted and I don't know if you have as well. Like we were talking about pedophile last week and now I guess my tinfoil hat is on a bit more and you're looking at all of the stuff that's coming out in the emails and thinking was this guy also just like a straight

up murderer like ordering 330 gallons of sulfuric acid. Do you know that he had a trapoor in his house that went to the sea which is like the perfect place to dump bodies? We now know that the FBI never searched his New Mexico ranch where it's rumored that he has bodies buried there, that the FBI wiped the footage from his prison cell and that they might have taken a dummy body and put it in the cell and that they slipped him out so no one would notice. Um, these quarterly payments to the head of

Ohio State's gynecology department that he was paying him thousands of dollars. Like what the [ __ ] is going on here? And also, this is very QAnon, but like all of the code words that they're using, things like white tuna potentially meaning a dead white woman. I feel a little Clare Danes and Homeland. Yeah, it's I think this is such a an erosion and degradation of our institutions because my understanding is the FBI

files or the Epstein files were compiled and aggregated by a law enforcement agency. And my sense is when a law enforcement agency uh aggregates a file, the output is supposed to be indictments, not a 1% semi, you know, sclerotic

[15:08]

release, non-release, redaction. We didn't redact things. We did such that millions of bloggers with a ring light could interpret it to their political advantage and find outrage where there shouldn't be any or excuse child rape as being mixed in with other outrage. And having Silicon Valley tech bros say, "Oh, well, you were there more times than me." And this is an unpopular opinion, but I think a criminal file should speak to the public. I think it's their job to use all their tools and go

through and say, "Okay, what warrants public disclosure and what doesn't?" Because I think what we've ended up doing is diluting all the crime. Now, whether or not information on Howard Lutnik, a cabinet secretary who lied about his involvement, and it was clearly more than that, whether that should be released, I can see justification for releasing that. But did he commit a crime? And if he didn't commit a crime and it's a criminal investigation, then it's fun to shame these people. And it's great fodder for interpreting it. It makes for great media and great clicks. And it's great for the Trump administration because

it's diluted the fear here that the president was involved in potentially um enabling a pedophile ring. But this has just eroded these institutions where it's like, okay, who can we trust to parse through this and figure out who is criminally liable here and get a subpoena from a a grand or indictment from a grand jury and who is on the wrong invite list. I think this whole thing has just been handled so poorly and will be looked back on as something

that absolutely molested and dented and just perverted the reputation of our institutions because we don't even know how to conduct an investigation and then parse it out and what the outcome should be. And it's something something that I've been thinking a lot about. Derek Thompson, who I had on Profy Conversation, said just as we've only been skirting along the surface of the atmosphere at 710 the speed of sound for about 30 or 40 years, 95% of the public was not taking supersonic travel or or

subsonic travel. Jet lag. Our species just doesn't know how to react to the sun coming up 5 hours before it's supposed to. So, our bodies get whacked with jet lag. Eventually, over, I don't know, 100, 200, 500 years, we'll adapt. Is our species ready for all of us to be broadcasters and for files like this to be released to all these people who think of themselves as people who can parse through this stuff and then broadcast it in a thoughtful way? They can't. And so this just seems like a melee where who gets caught in the scrum

is our institutions. And I think the FBI under a competent president with distinct branches of government charged with fidelity to their oath and what they're supposed to do would have come out with a subreport saying, "Okay, today we are announcing 24 criminal indictments against the following people

[18:09]

and this is the evidence against them. We have also disclosed the following people who are in positions where it's important to the public." Yeah. I just I think so much of this is just gossip and people not gossip but people who just love one of the things I don't like about our brothers and sisters on the left is we seem I think we need a massive redistribution of income and they're much more interested in a massive redistribution of virtue and yeah this person's a creep. Yeah, it's it makes your skin crawl but that the FBI isn't in the business of disclosing things

that make your skin crawl and make people look like creeps. That's not what they're there for. They're there for criminal indictments. And all of this what I'll call redistribution of virtue is diluting from the premise from from the whole shooting match here. And that is we need to put in place a series of incentives where no matter how rich and powerful you are, if you any way provide the infrastructure, traffic, or enable or conduct child rape, we're coming for you.

And it it strikes me that this is the best thing that happened. The way this has been parsed out sclerotically was a gift to the people who have actually committed crimes here because it's diluted the whole thing. Let's talk about Gelain Maxwell. Where do you think her case goes from here? >> I don't think anywhere that she wants it to. I mean, it's been really interesting to see the folks coming out of the DOJ's reading room. So, I don't know if you know about how it's designed, but it has just four computers in it. And there's

no way to your point about how poorly this has been done or or rolled out that there's no easy way to search through it. I mean, people are basically just taking what they can and reading it and you have to do it in the room. So, people are spending, you know, hours in there. Um, Rascin said that by his uh his team's calculations that it would take seven years to get through the files in the current conditions established by the DOJ. So, you have

that going on, which basically allows the administration to say it's all out there, even though redactions were done apparently by just like blurring out any female's name, which is is certainly not how to do this when someone like Colleen Maxwell is such a central player in this, but she's over there saying, "Oh, I want clemency." quiet anymore coming out of that room um saying that uh obviously she can't be granted any kind of clemency. Representative Paulina Luna uh said according to the files we saw, Galen Maxwell was engaged in trafficking and rape. I don't think she deserves special treatment. She's a monster. Um, so I think that if the administration was thinking that they could pull another move like what Todd Blanch did and getting her to that cushy prison because she quote unquote was going to exonerate

both Donald Trump and Bill Clinton because I guess they think that the two sides are as partisan dug in which I have not seen to be the case. don't think you can trust a single word that comes out of her mouth. I think her testimony is meaningless at this point. Um, she committed psychological and physical torture on these girls. is something built into us as the people who bring other people into the world that you should not be this depraved and sick. And I I think that if Trump is reading any tea leaves or Susie Wilds is, she knows that there can be no kind treatment for Galen Maxwell and that no one trusts anything that she says. >> Let's leave it there. We're going to take a quick break. Stay with us. Welcome back. Trump is proudly claiming we're already living in the Trump

economy. You just mentioned it. You said you inherited a mess from President Biden when it comes to the economy. >> But at what point is it on you? At what point are we in the Trump economy? >> Oh, I'd say we're there now. I'm I'm very proud of it. 5.6 6%. You know, we have a GDP of 5.6 despite a shutdown. >> But the reality is more mixed. Most Americans disapprove of his handling of

the economy. Consumer sentiment is still low and some of his growth claims are inflated. As Trump rolls out this barnstorming economic message ahead of the midterms, the question is whether voters will buy it or if rising costs and skepticism about his numbers could undercut Republican prospects. What do you think Americans think about the Trump economy? >> They don't like it. Everybody doesn't like it. I mean, maybe the richest of the rich. Um, but when doesn't matter the survey, the pollster. I mean, this been an interesting week because

right-leaning polls have now moved squarely into negative territory about Trump. Um, Ras Mutant's pollster has been posting a lot on Twitter about how dangerous the territory is that they are now. Um, so his net approval is minus 18. Um, 26 points lower than it was in his first term. um 53 points lower with independence. Um

House and now Senate is widely talked about as being in play. We assume that about the House obviously um but Senate is a big deal. Um the Journal did an analysis that the American consumer is bearing up to 43% of the burden. So, yes, the corporations are taking some of the hit, but the average American is feeling it. Um, too, and there were great special election results for Democrats again, you know, 30 point plus overperformances in

Louisiana and Texas, right? Like this wasn't happening in deep blue territory. I think that people know what's up. What are your observations about the economy and how how people are reacting? >> Well, 36% of adults say they approve of his handling of the economy while 59% disapprove. That's according to NPR and the Maris PBS News survey. Um about three in 10 adults rate economic conditions in the country as excellent or good while roughly 7 and 10 rate them as only fair or poor. And 71% are concerned about the cost of health

care. 71% also say say the income gap between the richest and middle class in the US is increasing and consumer confidence is lowest since 2014. In addition, the genie coefficient which measures I guess variance and it's applied to wealth. Zero would be everyone has exactly the same. If one person owned everything that would be 100. When the French Revolution happened or the kind of you know let them eat cake era uh the genie coefficient was at

about uh somewhere between 80 and 85. Today in America the genie coefficient around around wealth is 83. We are literally at the point where revolutions happen. Uh the number of billionaires has surpassed 3,000 for the first time. It's higher the level of wealth is higher than any time in history. Meanwhile, one in four people globally face hunger. Billionaires are over 4,000 times more likely to hold political office. The one I like is that if you're a kid from a top 1% income

earning household, you're 77 times more likely to get into an elite university. What I don't get though is that the billionaires themselves seem to be handling their own PR really poorly. That they [ __ ] post America or they seem to think that, you know, they're just not they don't come across as really grateful or civic-minded is the way the ones that get the most press are the tech bros who credit their grit and character for their success and then blame the markets for anything that's

gone wrong or blame the country. Uh Trump families pocketed more than 1.8 billion in cash and gifts since the 2024 re-election. But for other things, as you pointed out, things have got or other people things have gotten better. Um tariffs show that only about 4% of the tariff burden is shouldered by foreign firms and that a near complete pass through of 96% to US buyers. folks, this notion

[27:11]

that the firm itself or the uh exporter uh shipping goods into the US would pay for tariffs. No, 96% of those tariffs are being passed on to American consumers. The other big winners have been Silicon Valley's tech titans. Musk spent at least 55 million on supporting conservative candidates last year and he accumulated roughly a quarter of a trillion dollars under Trump in terms of wealth growth. Yeah, it's pretty bleak. And I think that that's the reason that their PR has not been going well because I think those

stories are actually being covered and that people are very conscious of it. Even if Yeah. Well, they feel it. They feel what's going on in their pocket and then that the upper class is walking around like nothing happened. And I wanted to get your take on this. So John Oaf, who is a vulnerable Democratic senator in Georgia, he kind of appears every few months and does a great rally and reminds people um that he's awesome. Um but he's been talking about income inequality and going against the

billionaires and you know the corporate class, but he rolled out the Epstein class at his rally over the weekend. We were told that MAGA was for workingclass Americans. But this is a government of, by, and for the ultra rich. It is the wealthiest cabinet ever. This is the Epstein class ruling our country. They are the elites they pretend to hate. If you're Steve Bannon and your pitch,

>> your pitch was Trump for the forgotten man and woman, how do you sell any of this? Trump was supposed to fight for the working class. Instead, he's literally closing rural clinics and hospitals to cut taxes for George Soros and Elon Musk. >> So, he threw in the left-leaning billionaire right into all of this who puts a lot of money into those DA races across the country, etc. And I thought it was such smart framing, right, to make really putting this as us versus them and we're willing to sacrifice

Soros in pursuit of that. What do you make about the Epstein class as a term? Um, and then also, how do you think do you think Democrats are doing a decent job of seizing the moment or we're kind of still just like receiving results rather than going out and making them ourselves? Yeah, I think that I think I think it's brilliant and and the reason it's brilliant is that I think if Democrats try to say all men are violent, all white people are racist, and all billionaires are evil, well, don't be surprised if you know you're

stuck with very left-leaning female non-whites, which you cannot win an election with. Those people will leave you. The donors will leave you. They'll believe you, but you're saying I'm evil. I I thought Mark Benoff took way too much [ __ ] He said something off, you know, dumb in my view about San Francisco politics. The guy's been an incredible civic donor and there's this

notion that, okay, all billionaires are evil because we have some tech billionaires that just seem incredibly weird and ungrateful. So, I love the idea and not only that, I think Democrats should wrap their arms around successful people and people who make a lot of money. And what they need to do is all right, you've controlled the House, the Senate, and the White House for periods of time, and yet every time you're in there, you lower taxes on these people. So stop stop bitching about the officiating. You're wearing a black and white striped shirt. Figure out more progressive tax structure and stop demonizing

people who make a lot of money. Stop demonizing young men. Stop demonizing or having a bias against white people. I there that's just not a winning recipe for elections. What is brilliant about this is what he manages to do is say there is a virus in America amongst people who tend to be wealthy, tend to be white, tend to be male, not all of them, who believe they're not subject to the same standards as everybody else, and believe they can get away with anything and believe they're

entitled to a level of depravity that no one else would would dare uh take these sorts of risk. and he's classified them as the Epstein class, which I think is brilliant cuz what it's saying is no, not not every rich white guy is a pedophile. I get that. But there is amongst this this group of people an Epstein class. So I think it's brilliant positioning because what it does is it doesn't alienate the Howard Schultz's of the world. you know, the it doesn't alienate

wealthy white guys who have traditionally been supporters of the Democratic party who at some point are like, you know, I I'm sick of trying to be your ally and you want to hang me at Dawn because I'm pointing the gun incorrectly. So, I think it's I think it's brilliant positioning. He's been very good. He's very vottoenic. Uh I'm going to give him some money just you bring it up. I like him. Several elite schools are now charging more than $70,000 a year, more than many top colleges, as families flee a struggling public system embraced from major changes under the new mayor. For some parents, it's sticker shock. For others, it's the price of peace of mind. Jess, this is something we both deal with. This is a story of privilege. >> This is why I submitted it to David. I

was like, Scott's going to want to talk about this. >> But what do I I got a I got I got a lot to say about this or a lot of thoughts. >> You go first. I always go first. withdrawn. Now what does that do? Okay, in exchange for us saying to you greater chance of getting in, you lose all negotiating all all leverage for financial aid. couldn't fill their class. And so they started offering scholarships. $58,000 to play with blocks. And they artificially against sequester supply. And the math I did is that I think every private school should be required to say the following. All right. invested in them. You have this situation where okay, everyone there's a massive overinvestment. Say you took that $50,000 or that I'm sorry, now it's $70,000. They don't get into an elite college.

Okay, people will say elite college doesn't matter. Yeah, it does, folks. I hate to break it to you. It does. of the market at 35 you can ease your guilt and your kids pain by giving them $4.5 million. So, it is very hard to argue that if you were to be disciplined and to take that money that you would spend on private school, especially in New York, and put it into index funds, you're going to be able to buy back a lot of potential mistakes and economic harm for that kid. Now, there are other reasons to send them to that school. And also, just so I can get the progressives angry, there needs to be more accountability from public school officials because New York

is not short on money spent per child. It's short on positive outcomes. it just we continue to have kids who are not doing well even despite the fact we spend more than a lot of places do. So the the sequestering of the 1% who have their own transportation, their own security, their own neighborhoods, their own education, their own health care creates a situation where the most powerful and some of the most talented among us are no longer invested in

America. And the number one indicator of a strong school in terms of outcomes isn't money, isn't isn't the kids, it's how engaged the parents are. And I saw this happen. I went to junior high in the 70s. In my seventh grade, you know, me and all my friends were there. And then in the eighth grade, they started busing. And all of a sudden, overnight, 40% of our class, a thousand kids, literally a thousand kids from Compton, black kids were bust in an hour each way. you know, in a bad [ __ ] mood

when they got there. And I wish it had been a Hallmark commercial. We hated each other. It was violent. It was ugly. We used to have black against white softball games and the faculty allowed that. >> That's the bad news. The good news is by the time we got to high school, we were all getting along. So, integration did pay off. And I actually think it's one of the reasons I have more empathy for people. My two closest friends was a Mormon kid who went to Stanford and a black kid who had to get a football scholarship to get to a school in Oregon. Immediately in the eighth grade,

my two best friends, Adam and David, their parents pulled them out and sent them to Winward, this Tony school. And I had one of those talks with my mom. So I'm like, "Mom, I need to go to Winward. All my friends are going there." And she's like, "No, we're I had one of those word different talks." >> Yeah. But the the wealthy the school system is yet another means of enforcing the cast system. And the only solution I

[39:15]

can come up with is to take that $70,000 price tag and make it a h 100,000 >> and redistribute that income back into public schools with distinctly harsher standards on teachers, administrators, and unions that if you don't get your scores up, it's going to a charter school and we're firing all of you. Uh but something needs to happen here. It's become the new enforcer, the cast system. Anyways, that's my TED talk. >> I agree with everything that you said and most happy, I guess, to hear that the marker of the best school for your child is proximity because we're opting

to send our oldest will go to public school next year. She'll start kindergarten. And it was a very hard decision for us to make because she has a December birthday. And inexplicably, the New York City public school system just puts all the kids who are born in the same year in the class. So, she'll >> Oh, so she'll be one of the youngest. It's not as bad for girls as it is for boys. There's I'm sorry to interrupt you, but there's research that shows the youngest boys in a class are more likely to be depressed because they're smaller

and they get picked on. But the same data is not as evident with girls who are the youngest in their class. >> Okay. Well, that's good news. And she's very tall. Uh she she has good tall jeans. Um, but so we're opting to do that. And as a New York City private school graduate, I had a lot of feelings about what kind of educational opportunities I was giving my child versus the ones that I was afforded. And this chart about the tuition costs really popped out at me cuz the school that I went to for high school was on it, place called the Dalton School. It was $35,000 when I went. It's $70,000

now. And I look at the world, right? I'm I'm out here functioning. I work with people who are paid tremendous amounts of money. My husband works in finance. He went to public school. And these are your average good public school, but just, you know, normal thing that a

parents that parents move to a certain place because they have a great school and they want their kids >> state. Yeah. >> Yeah. And they're they're not just fine. In most cases, I find that they're better human beings. A lot of them are more successful, but I've been much more focused on the quality of human than the level of academic achievement necessarily because I've just met so many and grew up with so many people who I don't want to be the folks surrounding my kids. And we'll see what happens. I I

hope that the school is fantastic for her and at some point we will end up in the private school system, but you look at that price tag and going back to what you were just saying about the genie coefficient for the US. It's just wrong at a certain age. >> But especially at that age, they're playing >> for five. Yes, I get it. And most of these schools go through the really good ones in New York City at least, they go through fifth grade and then most kids filter into the private school system

[42:15]

and they're set up for success with that. But the system needs to be smashed because you say, you know, take that 70k and invest it. A lot of for most people, they don't have the 70k, right? Or that they would be taking out loans to be able to do this and putting themselves into debt. But there has to be a real reckoning. And this goes back to the Epstein class, you know, formulation, right? Where you just say it shouldn't be this way. And a majority of people who are doing this, and this is happening in cities all across the country, it's not just New York City. It's because their parents have

generational wealth that they can help them. Can't even tell you how many people I know that are like, "Well, we're not paying for it, right? This is money that was set aside by grandparents." And it's creating this false sense of uh financial security and ego for these kids who are walking around like they're all, you know, like too big for their britches. We're saying, "Yeah, your granddad founded X, Y, or Z thing, right? or your your grandparents came from or your great-grandparents this incredible immigrant class and was able to pass

down this wealth so you could go to this school, but what are you going to make of it? Of course, people at the top, they're going to go to the Harvards and the Yales of the world, but there are plenty of kids are going to go to just average schools, right, colleges out of this. And then I'm thinking, you know, you spent hundreds and hundreds of thousands of dollars for them to probably not have as good of a or as fun certainly or well-rounded experience while they were in school. and they ended up at exactly the same place with no guarantee that they're going to have a better job when they're coming out of it. Um, so all for a meritocracy in this

of smashing the system that allows schools to be $70,000 a year and and hearing about also, you know, school just doesn't feel like it should be for profit. I I just I hate that, especially going down to the dirty secrets. The dirty secret is the nonprofits are four prophets wrapped in a sheep's clothing. >> So now you've just ruined everything for me. >> There's 16 administrators for every one person that teaches at MIT. I can tell you my colleagues are obsessed with artificial scarcity and means of every

every morning, not everyone, but the majority of administrators, the majority of faculty members are capitalists like everywhere else. And they wake up in the morning and they say, "How do I increase my compensation while reducing my accountability?" and they wrap themselves in nobility and raise tuition faster than inflation every year. When I I went to public school all the way through graduate school and seven years of tuition of undergrad at UCLA and graduate school at Berkeley, the total tuition was $7,000. And the UC system is still doing God's work. Yeah.

>> Still exceptional value. Probably the one of the best actors in the space. And now that would be aboutund the tuition for seven years would be $120,000. I mean it's a longer conversation but a lot of it comes back to cheap credit governmentbacked student loans accreditation that won't let competition

in. And also they in my view we need to revoke the taxfree status of any university whether it's Dartmouth or Harvard that has an endowment over a billion dollars that's not growing its freshman class faster than population growth because they've decided they're a hedge fund offering classes no longer a public servant. But we fall under the illusion that me and my colleagues are like nice, noble, good people. No, we're capitalists like everyone else. And unless we're regulated, we're going to [ __ ] the middle class. And that is exactly what we've been doing for the last 40 years. >> Thanks a lot, Scott. >> There you go. All right, Jess, that's

the episode. Before we go, if you're watching us on YouTube, make sure you hit subscribe. Thank you for listening to Raging Moderates.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell’s Testimony is “Meaningless”
item.description: New revelations in the Epstein files might complicate Ghislaine Maxwell’s bid for clemency. Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov discuss, on Raging Moderates. #trump #epsteinfiles #podcast
item.content:encoded:
[00:00]

You know how I am about women that do things like this. Let's talk about ghislaine maxwell. Where do you think her case goes from here? I don't think anywhere that she wants it to. Representative Paulina Luna said, “according to the files we saw, ghislaine maxwell was engaged in traffic and rape. I don't think she deserves special treatment. She's a monster.” I hope that there is some world in which Maxwell is moved back to the bad prison, and has to rot in there for the rest of her life. I don't think you can trust a single word that comes out of her mouth. I think her testimony is meaningless. She committed psychological

and physical torture on these girls. I don't know if I really mean this, but to some degree, the person who is recruiting and feeding these girls to Jeffrey Epstein almost feels worse. You know how I am about women that do things like this, where I just think that there is something built into us as the people who bring other people into the world, that you should not be this depraved and sick. And I think that if Trump is reading any tea leaves or Susie Wiles is,

she knows that there can be no kind treatment for ghislaine maxwell, and that no one trusts anything that she says.

item.title: Trump has become “Ineffective”
item.description: Whether he’s posting racist videos, or blaming it on the media, Trump’s old playbook isn’t hitting the same marks anymore. Jessica Tarlov and Scott Galloway discuss, on Raging Moderates.
item.content:encoded:
[00:00]

The is being called a bit more. >> Over the weekend, President Trump was doing what he's done for years, picking cultural fights. He went after an Olympic skier for expressing mixed feelings about representing the US. I think that skier probably represents most of us right now. Amplified a racist video depicting the Obamas and once again leaned into grievance and division. >> What really stood out to me is how ineffective I feel like he's become. Like he's really lost his fastball. I think they call it the weave that he does, right? where he like finds a way to get a question that he doesn't like and then he goes some other path and

somehow his base plus the extra 10% that voted for him understands what he really meant and all is forgiven and it doesn't really feel like that's happening anymore at least when it comes to these culture war things and on the horrible racist video of the Obamas depicting them as apes that came out Laura Ingram had Caroline Levit on and asked her about it said can you really throw a staffer under the bus and Levit tried this. Oh well, this is a leftist media narrative and she's staring at Laura Ingram. So, it feels like the

is being called a bit more. I'm not predicting some downfall of the Trump administration, but it does feel like he is not hitting his marks in the same way. And he's not able to dangle one trans swimmer in front of people to get them to come over to his side. and that people are actually observing what's going on on the ground and formulating a not so positive view of Trump and co as a result.

item.title: Epstein Scandal TURNS on Trump as Howard Lutnick Gets Caught LYING
item.description:
Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov sit down with Yale leadership scholar Jeff Sonnenfeld to unpack his new book, Trump’s Ten Commandments. They dive into Trump’s racist stunts like posting the recent AI Obama video to his “tribal chieftain” style of centralizing power. Jeff breaks down how Trump bends rules, gets things done outside traditional channels, and uses distraction and propaganda to shift the public's focus.
Prof G also talks with Prof Sonnenfeld about the Resist and Unsubscribe Movement, and what other things that business leaders can do right now to spark collective action.
For more on Scott's Resist and Unsubscribe movement: resistandunsubscribe.com
Follow Jessica Tarlov, @JessicaTarlov. Follow Prof G, @profgalloway. Follow Raging Moderates, @RagingModeratesPod.
#scottgalloway #politics #trump #jessicatarlov #jeffsonnenfeld #trumpstencommandments #venezuela #immigration #elections #democraticparty #democrats #midtermelections #electioninterference #january6th #2020elections #dhs #kristinoem #sarahpalin #trentlott #economicstrike #generalstrike #resistandunsubscribe #resistance #ceo #businessroundtable
Please support this channel by subscribing here: www.youtube.com/@RagingModerates
item.content:encoded:
[00:04]

Welcome to Raging Moderates. Jeff is an academic who decided he wanted to have a lot of impact outside of the four walls of his home institution Yale and has just a big footprint and hosts these kind of agoras of uh CEOs and in this moment his voice has never been louder and more resonant.

Uh anyways Jeff thanks very much uh thanks so much for joining us today. >> Uh Scott Jesse it's an honor to to rejoin you. Thank you very much. of Barack and Michelle Obama. How does this kind of provocation fit into the patterns you identify in Trump's Ten Commandments, your new book? >> Well, thanks so much. And we talk about in there is as various elements such as divide and conquer, as you know, in terms of how he divides uh business communities and and and influential uh institutions uh so that they can be subject to different tyades of v vindictiveness. Uh, and there's a little bit of that at play here, but in

particular, we have a chapter in there called the wall of sound that u that Scott, even you are perhaps too young to remember, but I bet you do. As the Phil Spectre, very controversial uh bad guy record producer who uh uh was known for having so many instruments blaring at once in this the same note, same harmony, is that it's a it's a a kind of a a distraction device that Trump has. Some people call it the the shiny object. Uh some people will uh you know call it the wag the tail and and

and applying it to Venezuela, but it's a way of uh of distracting no doubt about it that this is bigoted, hostile and racially offensive to put it mildly. Even though it comes out angry as as a midnight post, which supposedly some other staffer was on his Truth Social account

at the exact second at midnight, but nonetheless, people think wrongly that these are impulsive decisions, these are uh deliberate strategic devices. The Venezuela attack, however you feel about drug trafficking, the idea of Chinese and Russian ships surrounding Venezuela, that didn't work. and blaming the oil industry execs when they to a person told me they had nothing to do with it, no interest in it. Is that he just, you

[03:05]

know, looking for ways to change the subject off of Epstein, affordability, healthc care issues, uh that he tried the Venezuela of Greenland the week after that. There's nothing particularly ownorous or threatening that we had to go in to start to threaten the possible military and economic sanctions for Greenland. uh the the the seizing these um election ballots uh out of South Falton County. These are desperate efforts to change the subject from domestic largely domestic issues he doesn't want to talk about and using race is always a last resort of

scoundrels and he's not above that. >> Before I just toss it to Jess, I'd love to know based on your book and your research here, how do we of the ten commandments of Trump, how do we break the tablets? two hours to talk about that great question. It's a big one. >> I'm in it to win it. You guys go. That's the essence here is u we have these these 10 issues that everything all the power centralized through him. and strategy devices. It's like you don't you don't make any progress calling an alcoholic a drunk. >> Getting past the fingerpointing and trying to figure out what we do about it. It's collective action. That's how you take down a bully. Uh we have seen

it happen successfully in August of 2017 after the tragic killing of an innocent young woman peaceful protester in Charlottesville in August 2017. Uh Trump went on the air that was a Friday night on the air Saturday and made a a very underwhelming statement of sympathy and then somebody whomever Steven Miller I don't know advised him to go back into it again the next day Sunday and came out with the equivocation of the white nationalist who murdered this woman being you know good on both sides with the quivocation statement that led Ken

Fraser of MC one of four black CEOs leading a Fortune 500 firm at the time to say I've had it I'm out and he told his board you do what you want I can't speak for MC I'm speaking for me and the board fortunately backed is there's a slight delay the next day and we started calling through to all different offices of corporate America and that led to a mass exodus a stampede left the business advisory councils to this day the business roundt never made a statement on this but that was a

[06:07]

grassroots exit that made a huge difference they walked away from Trump and they didn't come back until in 2021 and January uh there's other than Elon Musk there's no support in the US business community on the trade front we saw the national association of manufacturers It was a pretty much arc right-wing group that was not interested in civil rights issues, wasn't interested in the Vietnam War, wasn't interested in environmental concerns, and that's why the business roundt was formed as a reaction to them of all things that that showed collective action. Uh, believe it or not, we actually unified 700 college and

university presidents to take a stand midappril last spring after Harvard and Colombia and other schools were being sequentially attacked. We saw the anemic response of law firms and thought, well, can't university world do better. Despite the the nonsense uh the BS of these institutional neutrality statements, these college presidents, university presidents uh overrode their own boards of trustees and came out with a very strong collective set of statements and those edicts stopped. So, it's collective action that does it. But

it can't just be the CEOs. I asked the CEOs, why aren't we hearing from more of you? and they say, "Where are the clergy?" Until Minneapolis, if your life depended on it, you couldn't name me five clergy, interfaith clergy, linking arms the way they did in the 60s and 70s to take a stand. Even now, with the exception of Minneapolis, we don't see the trade unions speaking out. We don't see the professional associations and and again, we talk about the campuses. Uh these voices which were very important in the 60s to be across sectors are somewhat muted now. Jos >> um I that was all really interesting and

now I have many directions that I want to go in but I I want to go back to something that you said in your first answer and you mentioned Epstein which is the kind of topic dour right now and as we're recording this commerce secretary Howard Lutnik is testifying um before the Senate uh he had a relationship with Jeffrey Epstein he claimed publicly that he didn't talk to him after 2005 Senator Van Holland kind of has him dead to rights on that and I want to play this clip and then get your response as to what you think Trump's leadership style at this moment is going

to lead him to do. So, let's look at that. I >> I think you understand the root of concern here. Did you in fact make the visit to Jeffrey Epstein's private island? >> I did have lunch with him as I was on a boat going across on a family vacation.

My wife was with me as were my four children and nannies. I had another couple with they were there as well with their children and we had lunch on the island. That is true for an hour and we left with all of my children with my nannies and my wife all together. We

were on family vacation. We were not apart to suggest there was anything unoured about that in 2012. I don't I don't recall why we did it. But >> Mr. Secretary, again, >> so I just want to note this is after Jeffrey Abstein is a registered sex offender. Letic said that he didn't interface with him after 2005. Based upon what you know about Trump's view and his leadership style, how do you think that he's going to handle having a cabinet secretary caught in this kind of lie and the attention that it brings to

the administration? >> Well, Trump doesn't ever apologize as we see with the racial situation. And we had somebody uh Trent Lot, if anybody remembers that name, who was the Senate majority leader, Republican Senate Majority Leader, made a a quote unquote off-color joke back in I don't think 2004 or so, saying that um if only STM Thurman had won in 1948 for president. That was enough to force his resignation. We saw people such as Wilbur Mills, the chairman of the Ways

and Means Committee on a indiscretion doesn't compare to these things or u or Dennis Hasser, N Gingrich, uh the Bob Livingston, former Republican speakers of the House all had to resign for things. There was shame not that long ago. We saw shame still matter and and what's happened here is atrocious. There's we have a chapter in there on on how he moves away from losers. uh that he's decided that Giuliani and whomever else uh uh Sarah Palin are too much of a liability for him. He me he doesn't have a a two-way loyalty. He doesn't mind

cutting things off. The challenge here, which is such a good question, Jesse, is we would predict from that chapter that he would drop Lutnik. He has overtly lied. You know, on that clip you showed, it doesn't demonstrate whether or not he actually perjured himself under oath, but we do know that he said repeatedly in recently to the media that, as you pointed out, was 2005, he had no more contact with

that disgusting person. And now we see that he not only built a house next door to him, uh, but he was investing in businesses for years later. He he stayed in contact for 12 years past. He told us he'd stopped all contact. and apparent if you take a look at the emails suggesting there was a trip to the island. We don't actually see the trip. We see the before and after. I don't know. But is that if he takes the move on Lutnik and pushes him out, which he should, does that start the quote unquote proverbial slippery slope where all the indiscretions of Hegsth and and

others start to spiral out of control? I think it's possible that um he could lose Lutnik. Lutnik is not popular on the cabinet. Obviously, this would make Secretary of Treasury Scott Besson's day to get rid of Lutnik and maybe take Bill Py with him. >> I was going to say I think he wants PY out out too. >> Yeah, they'd like to send those guys back to the bowling alley. I mean, this

[12:08]

is a lot of CEOs say Howard Lutnik is the Fred Flintstone of finance and and that these days would be a compliment. He's bringing nothing but shame. But the thing is with Trump himself with 38,000 redacted mentions uh in this report, how does he stop it from spreading? It's a great question. We would predict that he'd figure out a way of getting Lutnik out of there. U but u he will first try for a while the denial just like he said just a few months ago that this is a Democratic hoax. There's nothing to the

Epstein files after on the campaign trail saying this is the this is the answer to the Democrats uh pedophilia uh fraud. >> Yeah, I should check Poly Market for the odds that we strike Iran tonight because I know that's usually the go-to distraction. Um >> you're exactly right. It's something like that. Maybe they they need to to worry about this in in in Montaco or Likensstein or or Luxembourg, you know, or some other area of great concern to Donald Trump that he'll raid to distract us as a major concern or what blue city he's going to come after.

>> Well, I want to just say what you said about a shameless administration is so important and run by a man who doesn't feel shame. So, as regular people on the ground trying to navigate this, how do you think the American people, and this links obviously to what Scott is doing with uh people unsubscribing from these services, companies that don't seem to be taking a stand at anything against the administration, but how do you think that we can create an environment where some sense of shame comes back to our

elected officials? Obviously, winning elections is part of that. Um, but in the day-to-day, >> well, uh, here's the challenge is people watching CNN or MS Now or reading The Atlantic and trottling to themselves, "This guy's such a loser. He's so stupid." U, just because Trump uh, often appears uh, convincingly ignorant doesn't mean he's stupid. He's dumb as a fox. Pope and and John McCain and and people who are PSWs that he considered losers. Uh but we also saw that uh this disengagement that Scott talks about is part of an even larger spirit of voice. When I talk to CEOs about taking a stand right now, they're afraid. You know, he

look who he's attacked. He's attacked Jamie Diamond, the most feared and revered finance in the world, the CEO of JP Morgan. Uh he's attacked Brian Moyahan of Bank of America. He's he's attacked David Solomon at Goldman Sachs, stepping away from finance. He's a attacked Coca-Cola. What could that Coke is the most universal expression uh globally as Scott knows as a great marketer? Then the expression okay is expression Coke. He's taken on

Coca-Cola. He's taken on Delta Airlines. He's taken on um Harley-Davidson. Harley, what could be a more iconic American brand? That their very mascot is uh the symbol is is the u is the bald eagle. Their customers, the riders lead slightly MAGA. their workforce slightly anti-MAGA. The CEO just tries to pilot it down the center of the road because of reciprocal trade barriers from Europe against Trump. Harley had to shut down its plant because all of its bikes were made in in not just North America, made

in the US. They had to shut down a plant in Kansas City, open one in Thailand. Trump took that as a personal offense and said, "Don't buy Harley the stock plumber." They fired the CEO, Matt Levitage. Check it out. So, you know, that's a cautionary tale to CEOs. You can't act alone. But like Ken Frasier did is you can stimulate, you can spark as uh the last line in in in Ipsson's great play enemy the people is the strongest person in the world. He actually said the strongest man but he meant the strongest person in the world is the person who can stand alone is somebody who can set a model. We need

that but we also need that collective action. What else do we need? The CEOs who want to do something say you know we're not oligarchs. only three to five percent are the people that that Scott was one of the first to go after in terms of this oligarchic control of tech titans is 97 98% of them are hired hands they're salaried employees some of them overly salaried you know maybe some too well paid but still they they say we have to respond to constituents but who do they hear from they hear from red state treasurers they hear from red state attorneys general saying our

pensioners money in our state we want you to either be silent or be you know mildly somewhat pro MAGA the where the blue state attorneys general have been weirdly quiet quiet not to mention as we mentioned the clergy everybody else so we need to have that kind of pressure and as Scott talks about and Jesse was just echoing the consumer boycotts are just one part there's a lot of pressure that goes on whether or not because oddly enough a lot of consumer goods companies are not always the first to move these days but they do feel the sensitivity of public pressure so going after consumer goods companies matters a

lot >> jeeoff you know this you're a role model of mine we share a lot we're both academics we both want to have and enjoy having impact outside of the classroom. were both Jews. the people that you convene at a greater scale and density than anyone in the world. I've been to your CEO events. You bring together more powerful CEOs in a room than anyone in the world. the people that the president listens to? He's only backed away from threats to annex Greenland or tariffs when he hears from the markets or CEOs. You're their Yoda. You're their whisperer. What is it going to take for Jeffrey Sonnenfeld to get collective action from Fortune 500 CEOs? >> Scott, we have done it repeatedly. uh for example uh the the 2020 elections that Trump says were fraudulent. was the absentee ballots leaned heavily uh

towards Biden whereas in in person polling was leaning towards Trump and that's because the people who believed in science were less likely to go uh to the polling places because of co at the time uh count after count 64 court decisions endless audits and recounts and things and we convened the top 100 CEOs on 12 hours notice to come out with a a stand congratulating the winners to demand a speedy transfer of hour. Uh that made a big difference on the roll backs in 17 states on these crazy voting

rights restrictions. We brought them together repeatedly. So three or four times we we brought these CEOs together when it when it really mattered. They will. But they also hear from their constituents. You're right. Trump doesn't care what the clergy have to say or he wouldn't have made such a fool of himself at the national prayer breakfast on Friday. But he but those CEOs care what the clergy. They care what the trade unions. They care what the investors, what the community activists, what the campus voices, they care about all these stakeholders. where are those stakeholders? They're sitting home eating their steak, watching TV and chroling expecting Trump's imminent demise, and they're wrong. They have to speak out. Then the CEOs will respond. CEOs just can't say, "Well, it's my patriotism, my personal values, my ethics." No. Unless they're one of those handful of oligarchs, they're a custodian of other people's resources. they need to hear from those other people. As um Toqueville said when he came to the country in 1840, he wrote democracy in America, a French jurist. He wondered why do our laws work. He said it's not because of the tightness of the laws. It's the looseness of the

laws. They adapt the circumstances, but for them to work, what Toqueville said, it involves trust in the community. That means business leaders, he specified business leaders and other leaders of the community have to certify the truth. Toqueeville called it social capital. People think that's a newly invented term. Toefield coined it in 1840 and he said social capital is as important as financial capital. These people are the

[21:09]

pillars. They are the most respected. Sadly, legislators, federal, state, local, the media, academia, clergy have all lost standing in American society. Business leaders are still ascendant. My CEO in the Alamman trust surveys just last week and do still the strongest, most trusted voice as my CEO. We do need to hear from them. We have to give them license to speak for us speaking up and telling them to speak. They work for us. Tell them so. Jeffrey Sonnenfeld is a longtime Yale leadership scholar who has written a new book called Trump's Ten Commandments and

I would propose is the leader we need right now. Uh, Professor Sonnenfeld was really happy to hear from you and appreciate your time. Well, >> thank you very much, folks. Thanks, Jesse. Thanks, Scott. >> Thanks.

item.title: Trump Tariffs Cost U.S. Families $1,000
item.description: With wealth inequality hitting French Revolution levels, the U.S. economy may be at its breaking point. Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov discuss, on Raging Moderates. #trump #economy #politics
item.content:encoded:
[00:00]

What do you think Americans think about the Trump economy? >> They don't like it. Everybody doesn't like it. I mean, maybe the richest of the rich. Doesn't matter the survey, the pollster. Tax Foundation just came out uh with their appraisal of the Trump tariffs. American households paid $1,000 more last year because of the tariffs. I think that people know what's up. >> According to NPR and the Maris PBS News survey, 71% say the income gap between the richest and middle class in the US is increasing. In addition, the genie coefficient which measures I guess variance and it's applied to wealth.

Everyone has the same would be zero. If one person owned everything, that'd be 100. When the French Revolution happened, the genie coefficient was somewhere between 80 and 85. Today in America, the genie coefficient around wealth is 83. We are literally at the point where revolutions happen. >> It's pretty bleak.

item.title: “I hate to break it to you”, but elite colleges matter.
item.description: Private school tuition is hitting record highs. Is it worth it Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov discuss, on Raging Moderates. #politics #podcast #economy
item.content:encoded:
[00:00]

Private school tuition in New York City has officially crossed jaw-dropping territory. Several elite schools are now charging more than $70,000 a year, more than many top colleges as families flee a struggling public system embraced from major changes under the new mayor. By the way, there's a lot of research showing the best school for your kid is the closest, public or private, and reinvest that commute time back into study, sleep, play, time with parents. But let's say you send them to their local public school and you were wrong. They don't get as good an education. And to be clear, the average public school in America spends $15,000. The average private school 75. So over the course of

12 years, $720,000 funneled through an education system. It's going to pay off for your kids as evidenced by the SAT where lower income kids score 150 points less than middle- inome kids. And then hold your hats. Upper income kids score 250 points higher than middle class kids because for 12 years they've had another $60,000 in education, tutoring, counseling. If you took that $70,000 and you were disciplined and you sent it to Vanguard every year and send them to the local public schools, say you [ __ ] up. They don't get into an elite school. They don't get into an elite college.

Okay, people will say elite college doesn't matter. Yeah, it does, folks. I hate to break it to you, it does. And any parent telling you college doesn't matter anymore just found out their little Susie got a 22 on the ACT and is trying to make himself feel better. But say, fine. Okay, we put that $72,000 a year aside. The kid doesn't get into an elite school, doesn't get out of the gate strong, can't get a house. We [ __ ] up sending them to public school. If you had taken that $72,000 and over 12 years were disciplined about putting it in an index fund and the market went

up 9% at 35, you can ease your guilt and your kids' pain by giving them $4.5 million.

item.title: Pam Bondi IMPLODES Over Epstein Bombshell as Shutdown LOOMS
item.description:
Immigration enforcement suddenly halts in Minneapolis as Democrats push to disrupt ICE funding and shut down DHS unless major reforms happen. At the same time, Pam Bondi’s House hearing turns into a four-hour Epstein showdown — with survivors in the room and Democrats accusing the DOJ of stonewalling. Jessica Tarlov and Aaron Parnas (@aaronparnas1) break down whether Bondi just handed the opposition a powerful midterm talking point. Cracks are also forming inside the GOP. House Republicans defy Trump on tariffs, triggering primary threats and raising a bigger question: is the party truly starting to break ranks — or is this just symbolic rebellion? And with 130,000 jobs added in January and unemployment ticking down to 4.3%, is the labor market shaking off the trade war drama? Plus: RFK Jr.’s pivot from vaccine skepticism to “healthy eating,” Pelosi’s endorsement of Jack Schlossberg, Prince Andrew’s reported settlement money, and an Olympic controversy that has everyone talking.
00:23 Pam Bondi’s disastrous testimony 11:06 Cracks in the GOP’s support for tariffs 16:40 The end of immigration enforcement in Minneapolis
Follow Jessica Tarlov, @JessicaTarlov Follow Prof G, @TheProfGPod Follow Raging Moderates, @RagingModerates
Subscribe to our YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@RagingModerates
item.content:encoded:
[00:04]

five. I mean, it was just it it was kidding. >> I I was about to be like, I wonder if it was lower or higher rated cuz that that's what Trump is looking for. He's like, did we get a big number? [laughter] >> Um my big takeaways kind of are twofold. Number one, she didn't answer a single question. Like she didn't about the Epstein files or really anything that Democrats threw her way. I think number two, and people may be mad at me for this, but I thought that the Democratic plan going into it was horrible. I mean, like I I I think like yes, you have a

very combative witness, but also like do better in terms of cross-examining her. I think a lot of the members on the Democratic side just used it as a way to talk rather than like some of the for five minutes. co-conspirators and forced her to answer whether or not certain names were in there and then force her to go on record saying, "I can't answer whether or not Trump is in there." Right? And unfortunately for the survivors, I I tweeted out yesterday that [snorts] the real losers in the hearing, I mean, are the survivors. Those are the ones who lost. Like, at the end of the day, at the Democrats will move on, Republicans will move on, like Bondi will move on, but the survivors, they're stuck. >> Absolutely. I And I think the point

I mean, every fundraising email that I got was like, "Did you see me with Pam Bonnet? I had members of Congress who I'm big fans of, you know, texting me their viral tweets." Um, Pam Bondi was not going to answer any questioning, like even if she had been cross-examined properly, like you said, to push her on the 86page indictment, that that woman would respond, you know, well, the Dow

is at $50,000 or whatever. The level of disrespect for the importance of this story was so apparent. And I just I felt like at a certain point that people should get their grand standing in because this woman, whether it was a directive from on high or just that she actually is that soulless, had no intention of actually having a conversation about the contents of the Epstein files or how the DOJ had handled it.

>> Well, I think yeah, I mean I I agree with you. I think some members did a good job at that. like Crockett at the end, Jasmine Crockett. I thought her uh she just spoke for 5 minutes. And typically, I would say like, "No, you should ask her some questions, but she wasn't answering anything. You were the last person." And she pretty much read her to filth. Like I I fully was like, "Okay, great. Good. Good work, Congresswoman." I think for me, looking at Pam Bondi, and I've I've seen Pam Bondi in action for a long time. I'm from Florida. She was my attorney general uh growing up for eight years or so. She seemed really rattled up there. Like I don't I don't know why.

>> I thought so too. >> I I did not it she didn't come across as super composed or super measured. The burn book idea really to me I I get why she did it, but it didn't really land much. They can't get away from this story no matter what they're trying to

And uh from what I've read, uh Judge Piro, I'm like blanking on her title cuz she's just like Janine to me, uh brought in two prosecutors from Westchester County um that she used to work with to do this, which screams that there were probably a bunch of career folks who were not interested in bringing this forward, but it definitely is a big story. And I didn't connect those dots that that should have been at least a conversation when you have the attorney general in front of you as it continues with the vindictive streak of this

There were a few times where she actually like paused and you could see her mind working like what level of insane should I go now? and then the way that her voice was unleashed. And I've heard her give a lot of interviews at this point. I mean, she wasn't my AG, but I've I've consumed a lot of Pam Bondi um in the content sense. And she's usually pretty

Not that I said that he should uh be confirmed, but she seemed to genuinely not know what direction to go in. And I'm curious about this cuz I've been asking some people that I've

item.title: Howard Lutnick’s “reputation is in the sewer”
item.description: Yale School of Management’s Jeffrey Sonnenfeld joins Jessica Tarlov and Scott Galloway on Raging Moderates to discuss Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick’s congressional testimony about Jeffrey Epstein. #epsteinfiles #trump #podcast
item.content:encoded:
[00:00]

Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnik is testifying  before the Senate. Did you in fact make the visit to Jeffrey Epstein's private island? I did have  lunch with him as I was on a boat going across on a family vacation. This guy's reputation  is in the sewer. He has overtly lied. On that clip you showed, it doesn't demonstrate whether  or not he actually perjured himself under oath, but we do know that he said repeatedly into  recently to the media that as you pointed out was 2005. He's had no more contact with  that disgusting person. And now we see that he not only built a house next door to him, but  he was investing in businesses for years later.

He stayed in contact for 12 years past. He told  us he'd stopped all contact. Based upon what you know about Trump's view and his leadership  style, how do you think that he's going to handle having a cabinet secretary caught in this  kind of lie and the attention that it brings to the administration? If he takes the move on  Lutnik and pushes him out, which he should, does that start the quote unquote proverbial  slippery slope where all the indiscretions of Hegsth and others start to spiral out of  control? I think it's possible that um he

could lose Lutnik. Lutnik is not popular on the  cabinet. A lot of CEOs tell us after they shake hands with Howard Lutnik now, they want to wash  their hands. I mean, obviously, they feel soiled.

item.title: Trump’s racist post was a “desperate effort”
item.description: Yale School of Management’s Jeffrey Sonnenfeld joins Jessica Tarlov and Scott Galloway to discuss how racist AI-generated content fits into a larger pattern of political “commandments”. #trump #podcast #politics
item.content:encoded:
[00:00]

Using race is always a last resort of scoundrels and he's not above that. >> Last week, Trump posted a racist AI generated video of Barack and Michelle Obama. How does this kind of provocation fit into the patterns you identify in Trump's Ten Commandments, your new book? >> Those cartoons were not some subtle dog whistle. It was screaming racial uh venom at at the top of lungs. However, wherever he comes out on racial issues, he's using it strategically. Even though it comes out angry as as a midnight post, people think wrongly that these

are impulsive decisions. These are uh deliberate strategic devices. He tried Venezuela of Greenland the week after that, seizing these election ballots out of South Fton County. These are desperate efforts to change the subject from largely domestic issues he doesn't want to talk about. looking for ways to change the subject off of Epstein, affordability, healthc care issues, and using race is always a last resort of scoundrels. And he's not above that.

item.title: Why This Govt. Shutdown Might be LONG
item.description: Aaron Parnas and Jessica Tarlov discuss why Dems shouldn’t cave on the government shutdown this time around. #politics #ice #podcast
item.content:encoded:
[00:00]

Donald Trump took his most popular issue and flushed it down the toilet. >> There's going to be a government shutdown uh for a little while. >> Oh, you think that? >> 100%. I think it's going to last through Trump's State of the Union. I think it's going to be a prolonged shutdown. And I think that it's worth a prolonged shutdown because I don't think that any new money should be going to ICE in this time. I never liked the moniker abolish ICE. I actually preferred abolish Trump's ICE. Just this version of the department in the sense that like I don't think this version of the department should exist. I think that violent criminals who are here illegally should not be here, but your average

everyday undocumented immigrant who is here contributing to society should be here if they want to be. There should be a pathway to citizenship. I can go on my soap box all day, but I think that we'll see what happens in Minneapolis. I just worry that they're going to draw down in Minneapolis and then what? We're going to go to Springfield, Ohio, right? Like we're going to go to Philly. Where are we going to go next?
