I'm going to answer the question. >> And I told you about that, Attorney General before you started. >> You don't tell me. >> Oh, I did tell you because we saw what you did in the Senate. >> Lawyer, not even a lawyer. >> This is not a game, Secretary. >> I'm attorney general. My apologies. I couldn't tell. So, I was on an airplane while this hearing was going on and consuming these clips from the sky. And I feel like if anyone was watching my face, like they would never figure out that I was

watching a hearing cuz I thought it was like some insane movie where I was like, "Oh, no, she didn't." And then like, "Oh, is that really happening?" And then almost crying when she wouldn't even turn to look at the survivors, which seems like the lowest level of basic decency. What were your big takeaways? Number one, she didn't answer a single question about the Epstein files or really anything that Democrats threw her way. I think number two, and people may be mad at me for this, but I thought that the Democratic plan going into it was horrible. Yes, you have a very combative witness, but also like do

better in terms of cross-examining her. The real losers in the hearing are the survivors. Those are the ones who lost.

item.title: The Failed Attempt to Silence Stephen Colbert
item.description: After CBS pulled his interview with Texas Rep. James Talarico from the air, Stephen Colbert had some words for Trump’s FCC Chair Brendan Carr. Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov discuss corporate media “bending the knee” to the Trump administration, on Raging Moderates.
item.content:encoded:
[00:00]

James Talarico, the charismatic Texas state representative, was scheduled to be interviewed by Stephen Colbert on his show this past Monday night. But at the last minute, CBS told the hosts that the interview would not air and that he shouldn't talk about it on the show. Colbert doesn't appear to be complying. He called out FCC Chair Brendan Carr by name. On January 21st of this year, a letter was released by FCC chairman and smug bowling pin Brendan Carr. Well, sir, you're chairman of the FCC, so FCC you. It appears to be another example

where corporate media is responding to the Trump administration’s policies, or... desires, if you will. They're just ghoulish at this point, and they're more interested in the tiny fights, I feel like, than the big ones. Or maybe they feel like if they do the tiny fights, then we won't notice the big ones. But I feel like this is just going to be another L for them. It's a really bad look for these networks to constantly be bending the knee, and you don't get anything in return. That is the lesson we have seen thus far. You are not better off by doing this.

You're just losing money or brand value, which translates into money. I think it's important we're clear on what actually happened here. Paramount is trying to get regulatory approval for a merger, and the FCC chair sends a letter, not even a rule, but a letter about equal time, which is a ruse for censorship. And CBS lawyers immediately spike a guest booking on a show. That has three months left on the air anyway.

That's not regulatory or legal caution. That's a protection payment. And here, in terms of that payment, the currency is editorial independence, and they spent it on the cheap. Meanwhile, Colbert does exactly the right thing, defies the order. Talks about the defiance on air, posts the interview on YouTube, and the interview that CBS tried to kill will get more views in any interview they actually aired this month. They're not silencing speech, which is their objective. They've accidentally turbocharged it. The folks working on the Talarico

campaign for Senate are like, “who do we send the flowers to?”

item.title: Censoring Stephen Colbert BACKFIRES
item.description:
Scott Galloway and Jessica Tarlov break down how censoring Colbert backfired on CBS — after Texas state Rep. James Talarico’s scheduled appearance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert was abruptly pulled off the air. Is this corporate media caving to Trump-era pressure — and is Paramount the real loser? Then: the DOJ says it’s done releasing the Epstein files — but reports suggest the public has seen just 2% of them. If that’s true, who’s still exposed, and why is the department claiming mission accomplished? Plus: a DHS funding showdown is underway in Congress. With ICE funding already secured, and public trust in government near historic lows, which party blinks first?
00:25 Talarico-gate 10:28 How the DOJ has only released 2% of the Epstein files and what’s still hiding 35:55 The future of ICE
Follow Jessica Tarlov, @JessicaTarlov Follow Prof G, @TheProfGPod Follow Raging Moderates, @RagingModerates
Subscribe to our YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@RagingModerates
item.content:encoded:
[00:04]

Welcome to Raging Moderates. I'm Scott Callaway. >> And I'm Jessica Tarliff. >> In today's episode, we're going to discuss Taller Rico Gate, how the DOJ has only released 2% of the Epstein files, and what it's still hiding, and the future of ICE. Uh, if you haven't already, please make sure to subscribe to our YouTube page to get up-to-date coverage on everything happening. All right, let's get into it. James Terico, the charismatic Texas state representative, was scheduled to be interviewed by Steven Colbear on his show this past Monday night, but at the last minute, CBS told the host that the interview would not air and that he

shouldn't talk about it on the show. Colbear called out FCC Chair Brendan Carr by name. It's another case where corporate media is responding to Trump administration policies. Jess, what's your take here? >> Paging Ted Cruz. Remember how Ted Cruz was the voice of reason when this happened with Jimmy Kimmel just a few months ago? It feels like forever ago, but it was just a few months. They're obviously, you know, trying to run the same playbook. They attempted this with The View. Taller Rico was on the View um a couple of weeks ago. And you know,

it's disappointing that corporate media keeps bending the knee. Corporate law firms, corporate me, anything with corporate in front of it uh seems to not be doing that well, finding their spine in the Trump era. But I thought it was very well handled by Co Bear. And you know, I was one of the millions of people that immediately clicked that YouTube link and listened to the interview uh this morning as I was walking down here to record this podcast. And you know, it gave them a bit of a badass sheen that uh two kind

of arguably, you know, dorky guys like Steven Colbear and James Tarico wouldn't normally have. But I, you know, I think it's just another lesson in how things go during the Trump era. it will continue down this path and people need to continue to find their voice against it. I just like don't understand though why the Trump administration keeps committing these own goals, right? Cuz it's just going to drive people. I mean, I was going to watch James Terico no

matter what, but there are a lot of people who wouldn't normally tune into Colbear who don't particularly care about James Terrier or even know what's going on in the Texas Senate primary on the Democratic side who are now more interested in him. So, doesn't it just completely defeat the purpose of what they were trying to do in getting Terico off the air? >> I can't imagine if there were a conspiracy here, it would be that the biggest funer of Terico or the biggest uh proponent of the Tal Rico campaign, planted someone at the FCC and convinced

them to do this. >> Should we make Brendan Carr for Terico t-shirts? >> This is all of a sudden. So, first off, let's talk about the losers. Paramount CBS spiked a 60 Minutes story. Appears to have By the way, Anderson Cooper announced he's leaving 60 Minutes. >> I saw that's so sad. 20 years. >> Oh, I I'm I'm name dropping right now. I

[03:04]

know I know Anderson and I text him like smart move. He's He spent 20 years there. It's built his brand. He did a great job and leaving on his terms absolutely the right thing to do and it sends a very strong signal. And quite frankly, if there was an enterprising producer could probably call half the producers at 60 Minutes and raise $50 million from a from a Democratic uh billionaire and say, "I'm going to start something called um, you know, 3600 seconds and basically re, you know, reimagine 60 Minutes like it used to

be." I think that's a big opportunity. But it Paramount CBS keeps saying, "Oh, we're no longer an independent news network. We are the propaganda arm of the Trump administration and it's just not going to serve them well." And as evidence of that, the first week that they had their new anchor for CBS News, their viewership went from 5 million a night to 4 million. Now, I will see say this, it's keeping CBS in the news, which is literally going from irrelevant to less than irrelevant. So they're in

the news a lot, but for the wrong reasons. And uh so Paramount CBS, huge loser here, no doubt about it. The Trump administration cementss the notion they don't believe in a free press, which only massively juices the viewership of this interview. Uh the other loser, unfortunately, through no fault of her own, is Representative Crockett, who Tarico just got this wind in his sales where he's seen as this resistance fighter that everyone is so scared of. The Empire has put out all sorts of hits on him which makes him look like a

bigger threat. And obviously Cole Bear is an enormous winner here because he continues to look like, you know, his hat is just starched bright white. But this was effectively, you know, this wasn't censorship. Um, this was amplification. Brendan Carr just made Terico famous in Texas. Terico could have raised 20 or $30 million. it wouldn't have done as much for his campaign as Brendan Carr just did. >> It's also an interesting contrast. You know, we just had the Munich Security

Conference and the right-wing and Republican party here is always bitching about censorship abroad, right? And how we're the bastion of free speech here. And I'm I'm pretty sure that there's stuff on TV in Germany and in England that Brendan Carr would have his panties in a bunch about here. Um it's super embarrassing on that front. And you just see I mean no matter what story we're covering and you know we're going to

talk about the Epstein files, we're going to talk about what's going on with immigration enforcement and ICE. You just like tick down the line of lines of the Constitution and say, "Oh, guess this is irrelevant now. Oh, guess this is irrelevant now. Oh, guess this is irrelevant now. And it's such a huge opportunity for Democrats to come out and just be on the side of the Constitution, right? Like that these are

[06:05]

our core values that speech is protected. And I mean, hiding behind the equal time rule is not going to get you anywhere since Jasmine Crockett has been on Colar. And I'm sure Stephven Colbear would welcome Ken Paxton on to the show could talk about, you know, his legislative career, also his affairs, or John Cornin, who I think would have a much more successful interview, and he doesn't have any skeletons in his closet as far as I know, but he doesn't want to have his feet held to the proverbial fire over the Trump administration's policies. So, they're not interested in it. But this idea that, and this is why

I started with paging Ted Cruz, that there's no slippery slope here, and I hope that Democrats always stand on the side of the Constitution, but there are going to be ruthless people out there that once the Democrats come back into power are saying we should do exactly to them what they did to us. And they wouldn't be wrong for it. And the Republicans that are speaking out at this moment saying like, "Cool it, guys." You know, this is not a third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth term for Donald Trump in the

hopper, right? Like there's a big chance that we're going to lose the midterm. This is me being them, not me being a Democrat. Lose the midterms. Definitely the House. Maybe a lot of smart people think the Senate's in play. And then 2028, not a foregone conclusion at all, especially if you have JD Vance on top of the ticket. This is a very narrow way to be governing at this particular moment. And it's such a petty small fight. What do you care about 7 and 1/2 minutes of Steven Colbear talking to James Tarico about Christ? I mean,

that's literally what they were talking about. Like that billionaires are bad and that it reduces the importance of Jesus to make him a political issue. That that was the content that they were so afraid of. >> Yeah, I'm now comfortable calling the Trump administration fascist. That's the bad news. The good news is the really [ __ ] stupid fascists. They continue to make these sort of own goals around that just nobody thought to if you type this into an LLM and say
